objects: The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Senegal. The ensemble is (left to right, back row): tubano, ƞono. The three sitting are playing three distinct drums each. The left most musician is playing on the atswereshie and conducting the calls and form of the ensemble. The middle seated one is performing on an atswereshie, Eʋe sogo, and Eʋe Kidi. The musician in the far right is playing the atswereshie and Eʋe kagan.
dance; Ga; Senegal; tubano; ƞono; atswereshie; kpanlogo; sogo; kidi; Eʋe; kagan;
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Sobima. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): ƞono, shekeshe, atswereshie, atswereshie, Eʋe kagan.
dance; Ga; Sobima; ƞono; shekeshe; atswereshie; kpanlogo; kagan;
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Sanka. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): tubano, ƞono, shekeshe, atswereshie, Eʋe kagan.
dance; Ga; Sanka; tubano; ƞono; shekeshe; atswereshie; Eʋe; kagan
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs the Central Eʋe dance, Gahu. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): ƞono, shekeshe, Eʋe sogo, Eʋe kidi, Eʋe kagan.
dance; Eʋe; Gahu; ƞono; shekeshe; Eʋe; sogo; kidi; kagan;
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Kpanlogo. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): ƞono, shekeshe, atswereshie, atswereshie, atswereshie.
dance; Ga; Kpanlogo; ƞono; shekeshe; atswereshie;

The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Kpatsa, primarily practiced by Ga-Adangbe and Eʋe. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): ƞono, shekeshe, atswereshie, Eʋe sogo, and Eʋe kagan.
dance; Ga; Eʋe; Kpatsa; ƞono; shekeshe; atswereshie; kpanlogo; Eʋe; sogo; kagan;
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Femefeme. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): ƞono, shekeshe, atswereshie, atswereshie, atswereshie.
dance; Ga; Femefeme; ƞono; shekshe; atswereshie; kpanlogo
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Setse. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): Eʋe mba (bamboo clappers), ƞono, shekeshe, atswereshie, atswereshie, atswereshie.
dance; Ga; Setse; Eʋe; mba; ƞono; shekeshe; atswereshie; kpanlogo;
The Teshie-Nungua Cultural Dance Troupe performs Gome. The ensemble is (left to right, back to front): shekshe, ƞono, gome, atswereshie, atswereshie.
dance; Ga; Gome; shekeshe; ƞono; gome; atswereshie; kpanlogo;
Musician playing two kpanlogo drums with sticks
Map showing the predmoninant boundaries of various ethnicities in Ghana

A female dancer in the Kpeve village is seen displaying the physical embodiment of the transpossetion practice evidenced by chalk on the face, the staw skirt, and the ceremonial knife she wields. The knife is used to thrust into oneself in the straw skirt, often leaving scratches and abrasions.
The young prophets of the Kpeve village are blessed by the outer shrine in front of a physical depiction of Mawu.
A dancer in the Kpando village prepares for a ceremonial dance evidenced by the straw skirt.
Dancers in Tamale Gather in a circle for a community performance.
Kusun Cultral Center: Ga Perform Eʋe
Dancers at the Kusun Cultural Center in Nungua perform a variation of a traditional Eʋe dance with Ga ensemble accompaniment. Hunor Gatukpe Dogah directs the ensemble.
Kusun Cultral Center: Ga Perform Eʋe
Dancers at the Kusun Cultural Center in Nungua perform a variation of a traditional Eʋe dance with Ga ensemble accompaniment. Hunor Gatukpe Dogah directs the ensemble.
Kusun Cultral Center: Ga Perform Eʋe
Dancers at the Kusun Cultural Center in Nungua perform a variation of a traditional Eʋe dance with Ga ensemble accompaniment. Hunor Gatukpe Dogah directs the ensemble.
Kusun Cultral Center: Ga Perform Eʋe
Dancers at the Kusun Cultural Center in Nungua perform a variation of a traditional Eʋe dance with Ga ensemble accompaniment. Hunor Gatukpe Dogah directs the ensemble.
Elders dressed in white process through the road as part of the Homowo festival.
Instrument storage facility in the Ga region.
Houses in Tamale indicative by the clay walls and foundation with the straw thatched roofs.

Four barrell shaped drums of varying sizes are used to accompany a recreational ring dance. Instruments left to right: three bottle-neck drums [ʋuvi?], the two bottle-neck drums in the center seem to be positioned to be played as a pair. The tall drum on the far right might be a taʋugã.
A recreational ring dance comprised of side-stepping. Over time, the participant dancers move counter clock wise. Some dancers can be seen wearing ankle bells.
Hunor Gatukpe Dogah and Eʋe Drum Ensemble in the Kpeve Village
A drum ensemble in the Volta region performs for a ceremonial dance featuring the young prophets. Hunor Gatukpe Dogah is seen playing the atopani.
The Nunya Music Academy Brass Band performs under the direction of Prosper Gbolonyo.
brass; Dzodze; Eʋe; tuba; horn; trumpet; trombone;
The Nunya Music Academy Brass Band performs under the direction of Prosper Gbolonyo.
brass; Dzodze; Eʋe; tuba; horn; trumpet; trombone;
The Nunya Music Academy under the direction of Prosper Gbolonyo. Seen in the photograph (left to right): kidi, sogo, kagan, atsimeʋu. A djembe is also in front of the sogo.
brass; Dzodze; kidi; sogol; kagan; atsimeʋu; Eʋe
Elders dressed in white process through the road as part of the Homowo festival. One can be seen blowing into a horn [Lãdzo?]
Ga musicians seen performing on custom drums, resembling Eʋe atopani at Homowo.
